Habitat: Deciduous forests, open woods, brushy wastelands, and farmlands
Marshes and streamsides; sometimes moist forests.
Most common in moist fields, bogs, marshes, and moist woods.
Forests near streams; wet meadows with sedges or willows.
Among boulders along mountain streams, or in sphagnum moss along lakes.
Mature forests of West Coast.
Mixed forests.
Deep woods; open, brushy fields; moist sphagnum moss bogs.
A variety of habitats. In north, more confined to woods and wet areas.

Arid regions, especially in areas dominated by sagebrush and prickly pear. Sometimes found in woodrat nests or in large masses of vegetation at the base of agave, cactus, or other plants in desert areas.
Moist deciduous woods.
Open fields, waste areas, and sometimes woods, in well-drained soils.
Wet woods, fields, or swamps; sometimes relatively dry areas
Desert scrub. By day, roosts in abandoned mine tunnels.
Desert to semi-desert areas; in Southwest, rocky canyons.
Variety of habitats, from sage to high-altitude coniferous forests; mostly found in forested regions.
Areas along streams and lakes.
Woods and wooded streams.
Oak pinyon, and juniper forests; desert scrub
Arid Southwest.
Mainly coniferous forests.
Areas near ponds, streams, or lakes.
Trees and forest edges.
Forests and forest edges.
Both deciduous and coniferous forests.
Both deciduous and coniferous forests. In summer, roosts in protected spots such as under bark on in dead trees. In winter, hibernates in trees, crevices, buildings, and other protected places.
Variety of habitats, such as cities, parks, and forests. In summer, roosts in buildings and sometimes hollow trees. In winter, mainly in buildings, less frequently in caves.
Forested regions. Often roosts in buildings.
In West, scrub deserts and pine and pinon-juniper forests. Usually roosts in caves, sometimes in buildings, especially on West Coast.
Deserts and canyons.
Deserts and canyons.
Rocky cliffs and canyon areas.
Coastal, shelf, and offshore waters. This species will enter bays, estuaries, and shallow water.
Continental shelf and offshore waters. May move inshore in summer and offshore in winter.
Cold temperate continental shelft and offshore waters.
Widely distributed in coastal and offshore waters.
Cool temperate waters of the continental shelf and slope.
Coast coastal waters.
Coastal and offshore waters.
Coastal waters.
All oceans, often on the edge of continetal shelves but also in deep water and in shallow inshore water.
Favors continental shelf waters (but also found in coastal and offshore waters) at temperate and cold latitues; less common in tropical waters.
Temperate coastal and offshore waters.
Coastal and offshore waters.
In winter and summer found in coastal areas or near islands.
Shallow coastal waters, bays, rivers, and lakes.
Talus slides; rocky banks; steep, boulder-covered hillsides; usually at elevations of 8000 - 13500 ft.
Grasslands to creosote brush and deserts.
Brushy areas, old fields, and woods.
Rocky wooded or brushy areas, often with sagebrush.
Northern forests.
Barren areas, prairie, meadows.
Barren, grazed lands.
Brush-covered areas in coniferous forests, particularly yellow pine.
Piney woods, rocky cliffs, and sagebrush deserts; often abundant in open coniferous forest.
Open deciduous woodlands, foest edges, brushy areas, bushes and stone walls.
Rank vegetation, usually among dense hardwood or humid coniferous forest.
Deserts and foothills, from valley floor  to juniper belt; hard, gravelly surfaces. Associated with sage, greasewood, shad scale, and creosote bush.
Open areas, including rocky outcrops, fields, pastures, and sparsely wooded hillsides.
Moist coniferous or mixed forest; in mountains to above timberline; sometimes in sagebrush country or rocky meadows.
Flat, sandy desert areas; creosote scrub.
Nearly always associated with rocky locales such as cliffs, canyon walls, talus slopes, boulder piles, and hills along highways; oak-juniper growth in canyons.
Hardwood or mixed forests with nut trees, especially oak-hickory forests.
Woodlands
Woods, particularly oak-hickory; in the South, live oak and mixed forests, cypress and mangrove swamps, piney areas.
Primarily coniferous forests.
Often abundant in any kind of forest: natural coniferous forests, pine plantations, mixed, or hardwood forests.
Coniferous and mixed forests; may occur in hardwoods where old or dead trees have numerous woodpecker-type nesting holes.
Various deciduous forests such as beech-maple, oak-hickory.
Variable; alpine meadows, brushy areas, and arid grasslands.
Dry sage and sagegrass.
Coniferous forests, mixed woods, open areas; dwells in yellow pine, white pine, juniper, and scrub oak.
Rocky areas, talus slopes, valleys, and foothills to elevations of 11000ft.
Talus slopes in mountains, alpine meadows, and cliffs.
Meadows, old fields, and wooded areas.
Varies; deserts to mountain meadows, in soils ranging from sand to clay, with loan preferred.
Most often in good soil in meadows or along streams; most often in mountains but also in lowlands.
Desert scrub; in greasewood, rabbit bush, ephedra, and shortgrass; sometimes in short junipers and in creosote bush flats.
Sandy deserts, among cactus or mesquite, especially along streambeds or washes.
Dry, open, sandy weedy lowland areas.

Gravelly soils in desert areas, often in rolling terrain or in areas with ravines or rock outcroppings. Associated plants are rabbitbrush, tumble mustard, blackbrush, sand sagebrush, Mormon tea, and yucca.
Areas of soft sand, such as dunes; creosote bush or shad scale shrub.
Sagebrush, shad scale, and creosote bush desert scrubs, in a great variety of soil types.
Desert grasslands with scattered shrubs. Scrub or brush-covered slopes, often with creosote bush or acacia on hard or gravelly soil.
Rivers, streams, marshes, lakes, and ponds.
Early-stage dry weedy or grassy areas. Also deserts, salt marshes, and pine-oak forests.
Arid to semiarid brushland, especially in rocky areas; abundant at times in oaks, junipers, and pinons.
Deserts, especially rocky outcroppings with cactus or yucca stands.
Primarily wooded and brushy areas, but also many cultivated and open habitats, especially adjacent to woods.
Exceedingly variable: prairies and other grasslands, brushy areas, woodlands.
Pinon and juniper areas, preferably rocky cliffs and hillsides with ample brush.
Low desert with creosote bush, mesquite, and yucca.
Variable; often in arid situations, such as brushlands of dry plains and deserts. Often associated with prickly pear cactus and pinon-juniper; also dead trees.
Rocky situations; coniferous forests.
Desert; pinon-juniper areas.
Redwood forests.
Grassy meadows from sea level to mountains.
Coniferous forests, but clear-cut and grassy areas support more individuals; brushy and grassy areas, usually on drier upland slopes.
Dry grassy areas far from water, mountain slopes, and alder and willow-sedge areas.
High mountain meadows; valleys associated with dry, grassy areas.
Cool, damp forests; bogs & swamps.
Lush, grassy fields; also marshes, swamps, woodland glades, and mountaintops.
Deciduous woodlands with thick leaf mold or thick herbaceous ground cover; sometimes park-like grassy areas.
Along alpine and subalpine streams and lakes, especially along clear, swift streams with gravel bottoms.
Fresh, brackish, or saltwater marshes, ponds, lakes, rivers, and canals.
Grassy meadows; sometimes ne forests; often dry broom sedge; seldom bogs.
Mainly moist fields, but also brush, brushy fields, marshes, stand of touch-me-not, and woods with thick vegetation.
Variable; primarily moist fields, thickets, and woodlands, especially where grasses, sedges, or other green plant cover is dense; grassy edges of streams, ponds, and lakes.
Variable; primarily moist fields, thickets, and woodlands, especially where grasses, sedges, or other green plant cover is dense; grassy edges of streams, ponds, and lakes.
Deciduous, coniferous, and mixed forests; also in West, dry scrubby areas with scattered trees.
Open plains, brushy areas.
Open tundra and forests.
Shortgrass prairies and other arid areas.
Varied; mixed cultivated and wooded areas, brushlands.
Varied; more often in wodded and brushy habitats.
In East, primarily forests and swamps; In West, forests and wooded mountains seldom higher than 7000ft.
Somewhat open countyry, usually in mountainous areas; also along coasts and rivers.
Rocky shores and coastal waters along them.
USually islands: sandy or rocky beaches; occasionally caves protected by cliffs.
Coastal waters, mouths of rivers, beaches, and rocky shores.
Waters along rocky coasts and islands.
Varies; usually rocky situations, such as jumbles of boulders, canyons, talus slopes, and rock piles; less commonly wooded areas with hollow trees; sometimes around buildings.
Various wooded and wetland habitats; common along wooded streams. Often found in cities and suburbs as well as in rural areas.
Mountain forests, usually near water; also rocky, wooded canyons.
Forests, primarily coniferous, with numerous dead trees, branches, and leaves that provide cover for rodents.
Mature, dense, coniferous or mixed coniferous-hardwood forest with closed canopy.
Varies; open woodland, brushy areas, grasslands, wetlands.
Varies; forested, brushy, and open areas, preferably near water.
Along rivers, creeks, lakes, ponds, and marshes.
Forest and tundra.
Open plains and prairies, farmland, and sometimes edges of woods.
Mixed woodlands and open areas, scrub.
Desert, woodlands, grassy plains.
Mixed woodlands and open areas, scrub.
Foothills and brushy areas.
Primarily along rivers, ponds, and lakes in wooded areas, but otters will roam far from water.
Coastal waters within a mile of shore; especialyl rocky shallows with kelp beds and abundant shellfish.
Mountainous, semi-arid terrain; subtropical and tropical forests and swamps.
Forested or brushy areas and dense chaparral.
Deep, coniferous forest interspersed with rocky areas, bogs, swamps, or thickets.
Primarily scrubby country or broken forests - hardwood, coniferous, or mixed; also swamps and rocky or brushy arid lands.
Variable: desnly forested mountain terrain, brushlands, dry ridges, and swamps.
Variable: in summer, chiefly high, open mountain pastures; in winter, lower wooded slopes, often dense in woods.
Mixed habitats: forest edges, mountains, and foothills.
Brushy areas, woods, and suburbs.
Spruce forest, swamps, and spend and willow thickets.
Grasslands, also grassy brushlands; and bunchgrass-sagebrush areas.
Varied; primarily plains, prairies, and river valleys; sometimes forests.
Rocky, mountainous areas above timberline.
Semi-open precipitous terrain with rocky slopes, ridges, and cliffs or canyons. Grassy vegetation necessary with scattered shrubby plants; water essential in desert regions.
